title: Ticket #1017: Unable to restart collector with condor_restart on remote node
description: Unable to restart collector remotely by 'condor_restart -subsystem collector -name <target hostname>'
remarks:
2009-Dec-02 17:15:07 by zmiller:
rob, can you attach your patch?

from what you told me, i think this patch will solve the problem short term and i will probably put it in to the stable series (after i see it). long term though, we want to move away from forcing FQDN to be present in the name so that condor doesn't have to rely on DNS.

there is currently hard-coded logic to look for an '@' sign in the name, and if it's present, we query the collector for that name and it actually doesn't matter if whatever comes after the '@' is a real hostname or not.

the problem is if there is no '@', then we assume whatever is there IS a valid hostname, and that's where this breaks. IMHO opinion we should remove this logic so that whatever is specified in name can be a free-form string (although there does need to be a little bit of logic for being able to use a short hostname "north" in place of a FQDN, "north.cs.wisc.edu".) however, that change is not something i'd do in the stable series.

given the current state of things, i'd probably recommend NOT adding the FQDN if the Name already contains an '@' sign. otherwise append '@FQDN' to the COLLECTOR_NAME, or just use the hostname if COLLECTOR_NAME is blank.

2009-Dec-02 18:17:52 by matt:
When I was last in this part of the code I got the impression that DNS is used a lot to assist in the shorthand you mention, north -> north.cs.wisc.edu. I imagine that was from days before regexp in ClassAds. We should probably use that instead these days.
attachments:
• collector_name.patch 864 bytes added by rrati on 2009-Dec-03 21:03:06 UTC.
    This patch will append @FQDN to the COLLECTOR_NAME when registering it's daemon ad if the COLLECTOR_NAME doesn't have an @ in it.
